commentBody: I guess Nathan Hale was wrong when he said he only had one life to give for his country. Here is writing crosswords for his country 250 years later...

Seems I can't finish a puzzle these days without making a typo that I then gotta find and fix. And this one was no exception. Oh, well.

(Nice puzzle, though!)
Fun puzzle.  Was breezing along at a Monday pace, then could not for the life me get 43D. Even when I brute-forced it, I said SEERED?! Like what you do to a steak?

This easy puzzle was as SUITE as a CANDYCANE.

Just 1 second slower than my personal best.

Ahem. Is CANDY CORN a ‚Äútreat‚Äù, though?

Give me a Cinnamon Cannoli or a Cr√®me Caramel instead, please!

Enjoyed this very much. CSUITED my sweet tooth to a tee. Got all the themes and the revealer. As a teacher appreciated the AMSO, SAYSWHO, and CUPCAKE clue.
Happy Holidays everyone. Three more sleeps til Christmas

14 mins faster than usual so based on that makes it an easy one for me. No complaints or judgement though as it had a nice chill vibe making it a fun solve. Looking forward to Thurday's Christmas puzzle and trying to solve under the spell of a festive food coma!

Fun easy Tuesday.

One clue I only got last only with guessing every possible letter, ENBANC.  I do not understand that clue.
Smooth solve right up until I forgot how to spell VIGNETTE and thought the Nobel Prize winner could be OLnA.

Cute how many additional C's appear in this puzzle, the whole thing is a C-suite! 

I also noticed that not only do we have STEP UP and DIAL-UP, but a fair few entries to which UP could easily be added: shook up, scoop up, save up, use up, eat up, sip up (that pina colada) and cut up (your seered steak) and better caesar up your salad, too! Upon my word!

Nathan Hale had a great puzzle on March 26 of this year that's been nominated for The Griddies, featuring black squares that stood in for the four bases in baseball, such as NOT MY ‚¨õ RODEO ... worth looking at again. Dude's pretty clever, or should I say ASTUTE.

Today was an easy yet easing Tuesday puzzle. Had a brain fart and was confused until I remembered "suite" isn't pronounced as "suit."  ü´†

I liked the puzzle, except for one little nitpick. 5D, "Playground Retort," is SO lazy imo. I get it's a Tuesday, and it's probably the only way besides a fill-in-the-blank to clue this, but still. (Btw, I do also realize "AMSO" is the only 4-letter word, right?) 

Overall, I still like the crossword. Very cute, I have to say, and very "suite." Welp, C you, and Merry Christmas to y'all! üéÖ

A tasty puzzle, full of goodies, and a treat to work.  Thank you, Nathan!

(I'll pass on the CANDY CORN, though)
Sweet Tuesday! Two early week puzzles in a row with more interesting fill than usual, an interesting theme and some clever cluing. Keep them coming!

somehow shoehorning in a kwanzaa treat to give us the december trifecta instead of the halloween callback would have elevated this puzzles game, imo, perfectly adequate tuesday though it was.

black cake cookies and chocolate macaroons (cookies?) come to mind as clue seeds...
Sugary or twee? Easy one for the locals.

I‚Äôve been missing cross word input & culture vignettes from Andrzej. Hope all is well.

Enjoy this sweet & breezy Tuesday puzzle

If you're not talking with your local Christmas cookie baker, Yule want to batch things up.

(Otherwise you'll feel crumby.)

Maybe it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve never stopped loving CANDY CORN that CHOCOLATE COrN for Hanukkah looked very yummy till crosses snatched away. 

Always love me a Nathan Hale puzzle. Light, breezy, and fun‚Äîjust what the doctor ordered for the post-trip-to-the-mall-a-day-before-Xmas state of bodily shock. Granted, I thought it should be single malt Scotch instead, but we did buy that for a stocking stuffer. 

Thanks, Nathan.
A nicely Toughened Up Tuesday with a sweet theme.  Fun to solve.

My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/12/22/tuesday-december-23-2025/#ny I also reviewed the Sunday puzzle, but I forgot to post a link here. https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/12/20/sunday-december-21-2025/#ny

Like others here I‚Äôm missing @Andrzej‚Äôs commentary. Today would a delicious delight. 

None of the CCs were part of my cultural heritage in the contexts they were presented and thus the puzzle felt a bit chewy. 

CHOCOLATECOINs used to be everywhere. I was given some very special ones for Xmas some years ago. Not particularly connected with a religious event for me. 

I have no concept of what CANDYCORN is and I‚Äôm probably better off for it and that goes  for a CHRISTMASCOOKIE as well. 

The ignorance of KEMP meant the spelling of KAKHI with a C was the last to fall 

Thanks and enjoy the end of year festivities
Count me in the P Suite, preferring PIZZA PARTIES, PEPPERMINT PATTIES, PUMPKIN PIES, and ... PICKED PLUMS. Yes, the famous picked plums. That's why I solve, not construct.

Had to come here to find out that I was DOOKed by SEERED. 

üòÄ
How is the The Simpsons bus driver "appropriately" named? It's there a joke there that I'm missing?
This puzzle is way too easy for a Tuesday. This is after you got Lasik.
Yum! Thanks Nathan. Happy holidays.
Thanks, Nathan, for this fun puzzle! Y‚Äôall have a great Tuesday!
Am I alone in thinking that cupcake doesn't really fit with the other theme answers since it's only one word?
TIL when ski jumpers squat down as prepare for lift off, they‚Äôre sitting in the CAT CHAIR

A nice sweet treat for the holidays.  Thanks, Nathan!

Now I feel like making a crumb cake.

Very nice.
I wonder how CHRISTMAS COOKIES are different from the usual type? Anything like European Lebkuchen?

I wonder when it became usual to say HATE ON rather than just HATE? It's creeping into BrEnglish.

Enjoyable.
Delightful. How are those C-words in a suite? Hannukah does not precede Halloween, and where does a school party fit in that?
No Wicked or Swift clues gets Nathan an A+. Cheers.
Happily for me today, my Dad (now 79) still likes to sail his scow during warmer months. I didn‚Äôt know they also have a US variant, apparently larger and faster. Merry Christmas

I almost got stuck on the upper right corner--I could not let this stand on a Tuesday! With a cry of "I only regret that I have but one morning to lose for this puzzle," I managed to power through before having to get ready for work.

This was a real truite!




Et tu, emu.

Enjoyable Tuesday puzzle. Typical workout for me, and the reveal was one of the last things I filled in. That was just a nice 'aha' moment when I paused and reviewed and finally got it.

One puzzle find today was inspired in a roundabout way by CANDYCORN. Wondered about...

JIMMYCRACKCORN

And.. it was an answer once - in a Saturday puzzle from January 23, 2010. 

And... came across a quite remarkable puzzle find. I'll put that in a reply. 

....
With all due respect to his fans, but Shawn Kemp is not a Tues puzzle NBA star. (Maybe Sat?)

I liked this tight theme and its spot-on revealer, as well as the left-right symmetry, the three palindromes, the COIN and CASH echoes of yesterday‚Äôs SHORTCHANGE puzzle, and the septet of answers ending with a schwa (including PINA and CICADA, and when you put them together, it sounds like a drink). 

Amazed to find that AND CUT has never appeared in the 80 years of NYT puzzles. 

The Hanukkah gelt shot me back to my youth, happy memories of sitting around a big table in a small apartment with generations of family during that holiday.  Those coins were hard to open, but oh the reward!

Oh, I saw the double-C theme answers, and saw their sweetness, but my brain finally uncled after burning many ergs trying to guess the revealer without reading its clue.  My ego sighed, but my brain adored the work.

Happy brain, happy memories and the beauty of a clean, well-built puzzle.  One terrific springboard for the day.  Thank you, Nathan!

Nice puzzle, with a solid theme and seasonally appropriate themers. Enjoyed this one.

In the corner of our family room, we have a cozy recliner, which we've more or less ceded to our feline companion. We call it the CAT CHAIR. All the fur left there used to make me SEERED, but I've come to accept it, and now I DOOK.
C SWEET! love that theme!
Georg Philipp is coming over this morning to help bake Lebkuchen: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z2Stmfi26hA&list=RDZ2Stmfi26hA&start_radio=1

Let me be the 125th to note that our constructor claims to be "Nathan Hale."  Very SUS.
But...
Moviing right along, where's the EGGNOG?  And the PECAN PIE?
In a previous century, our mom baked sugar COOKIEs (shaped with the 'gingerbread man' cutter) and decorated them as Santas, using fondant icing.  
Our CHRISTMAS EVE dinner tradition is a big baked lasagna; our neighbors--an older couple with no grands--came to the festive table and shared the anticipation.  I made the pasta, so we're ready for tomorrow.  
Oops.  The puzzle!  
Okay....how did the Halloween CANDY CORN get in there?
A lot of phrasals (lol)

Fun Tuesday! But the definition of SUS used in this puzzle is, well, sus... That is to say, the definition is a bit odd, and I'm skeptical that it is what it claims to be. I wonder if it could be... an imposter. SUS origins: https://knowyourmeme.com/memes/sus

Now I'm Craving Confections.

Cherry Cobbler with Coca Cola?

well, probably not together.

Need to confirm that shipment of Christmas Crackers!

Jackie Gleason upon checking in: 

"How Suite It Is!"

Nice puzzle.  Thanks.

So, a couple nights ago, I solved an archived puzzle, from a Friday in 2019. Afterwards, I read the Wordplay column--it was one of Deb's "First pass Fridays," which I've always enjoyed. And, of course, I read the comments.

But that got me wondering about earlier Wordplay columns--my understanding is that Deb began writing Wordplay in 2011(?), but, looking this morning, the earliest I could find a link to was from July, 2017--but, when I read it and the comments, it seemed that it had been running for quite a while.

Any clues?
Oh no! Ear worm!!!!!!

Rats!

How could anyone mess with Escape, The Pina Colado Song?

It's silly perfection.

Happy Holidays to all my moanin' groanin' rootin' tootin' boastin' toastin' always postin' online amigos and amigas!

Fun one today -- thank you, Mr. Hale!

Happy Tuesday, everyone! Big snowstorm headed our way -- just in time for a white you-know-what!‚ùÑÔ∏èüéÑ

Am I the first (yeah, probably; and probably the only) person to explain that "gelt" means money? Not coins, not chocolate coins, just money. For Chanukah, we give/get chocolate gelt. 

I have fond memories of my father-in-law saying to Mom-in-law, with a little tap on her arm, "Give gelt" before he would take my kids out for a treat. He made the money; she guarded it. 

My dad would say the same to my mom when we were out to dinner, before credit cards were the norm for paying a bill. "Give gelt, Git," he would say. "Git" was part of her name. 

The result of all this was that my kids, on allowance day, would tell us it was time to "give gelt." Hah. I haven't thought about that in years! 

My daughter just completed a Duo Lingo in Yiddish. I think we'll have a discussion about this. Partly in English. She has learned such useful phrases as "My parrot likes pickles."

Why is Otto "appropriately named"? Is it because it kinda/sorta sounds like "auto"? If so, isn't that quite lame as clues go?

It's gotta be something else?

Anyone else quibble with "seered"?  Not in common usage as far as I can tell.  Cambridge dictionary doesn't come up with a definition.  And Sam identifies "task" as a challenging answer, so this seems a little problematic.   thanks.
Had it not been for SEERED ( couldn‚Äôt see it as two words!), I would have solved the puzzle. Even though tricky in places, I still enjoyed it. Fun mix of easy and brain twisting.

Three days in a row of charming puzzles! Thank you Nathan for this sweet treat. 

Happy Eve of Christmas Eve!!
Sorry gang, re, CANDYCORN, could not resist: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Ml0Lx9l1hI

I solved the puzzle, got the music and the congrats, but the timer's still going, the puzzle's not marked complete, and I can't change any entries. 

Be a shame to break a streak because of a bug.
I filled in 2D through the crosses, so never really saw the clue. When I looked at my completed puzzle, I spent way too long trying to figure out what a CAT CHAIR might be.

late to the puzzle today, but a easy, breezy one.  I really came here to say that CANDYCORN is not a treat of any kind.  




Even for Emus

Fun and surprisingly quick and easy for me. My best Tuesday time yet. I saw the top execs clue and then got the other ones based on that. No use trying to fit in fried potato pancakes or latkas with applesauce.

Got delayed by SEERED for far too long. I did
SEERED by the end. üò°

Several people have admitted to being dooked by SEERED--I've listened to that Chevelle song enough times to not be fooled by that.
OTOH, CATCHAIR completely mystified me--what the H is a "cat chair," and how do you use it? I've heard of (but never used) a T-bar, but that's for going up the slope, not down. 
Were it not for @EH's Diary review, I'd still be lost.

Glad to check the comments and see I wasn't the only person who thought 2D was CAT CHAIR. I also caught onto the revealer quickly, so a very fun Tuesday (and my last day of work before the holidays!).

One more puzzle find. Quite amazing. A Sunday from August 19, 2010 by Derek Bowman with the title "Going for a run." The only hint to the theme was that the clues for the theme answers were italicized. Otherwise those were straightforwardly clued: Here are some of those answers in order. ARMYBRAT CARBONDATING EXHAUSTFANS GRAYHAIRS INSIDEJOB KITTYLITTER MIXEDNUTS OUTERPLANET QUICKREAD SPEEDTRAP USEDVEHICLE WINTERXGAMES YEARZERO Think about it. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/29/2010 ...
Has anyone heard back from the NYT crossword department lately? I've sent them a few emails in the last month, but haven't heard anything back.
My first puzzle with NO hints, lookups or cheats! Doubt if I‚Äôll ever say that about a Sunday but I‚Äôll take the win where I can!

Once again KHAKI has been clued as yellow and brown. Am I suffering from a very particular case of colour-blindness? Greens, browns, tans and beiges, all present and accounted for in any khaki I've seen. But yellow -- nope.
I‚Äôve had to look up Nathan Hale.

I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle and even more so enjoyed the number of comments about CATCHAIR.  We share our home with four felines and as you can imagine every horizontal surface equates to a cat resting place, no matter it's original purpose!  I wonder how many times a day my husband or I say, "I'm coming back and taking my chair back, Kiki/Nala/Otis/Milo."  Now that my Tuesday puzzling is complete, I'm going to make some of those CHRISTMAS COOKIES that were also mentioned.  Happy holidays one and all!!

Thanks for a fun and cheery puzzle Nathan Hale. I‚Äôm a bit stressed out from all the holiday activities and this was a wonderful distraction. 
The Christmas cookie theme was especially fun because I just made a batch of cookies‚Äîvery easy ones with no oven involved, called Coconut Joys. I used to make many other kinds every Christmas but now my daughters and grandsons make many of my old favorites, which is great. Lucky me. 
Happy Holidays to you all.
SUHWEET!

I managed to fill in the pina colada song clue without getting it stuck in my head.

Then I read the comments, and thanks to the commentariat, the song is now living rent free in my head. Though, courtesy of Lewis (I think?) what I am singing is: do you like pina cicadas‚Ä¶ That makes the experience slightly better.
This was probably more of a Monday than a Tuesday but it‚Äôs my first gold star in 13 days and I‚Äôll take it.

Judging by 13D and 31A, this puzzle must have been submitted before Jan. 20.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
Nice clues, but seems easy for a Tuesday!
I just noticed a puzzle I finished but didn't get credit for.  Anyone know the email address for the crossword software techs? I can't find it anymore.  Thanks.
When I first hit 20A I tried POTATO PANCAKE, which fits into the same space.
Today‚Äôs ease was some justification for feeling Monday was trickier than usual. Still pondering the way the school bus driver is fitting‚Ä¶

Fun puzzle! My last word was 4D because the whole time I thought it had something to do with identifying as a wrapped gift. Like hiding in a giant bachelor party cake and jumping out (no, never have, and in my 60's now so not likely). Or maybe a stowaway pretending to be a present. Or a Halloween costume. I thought geez, what a weird clue, must be some cultural reference I'm missing. Lol.

Monday Tuesday got switched this week. This one was more enjoyable albeit quicker. What can I say, I like an 8 minute puzzle I guess? Just wish there were more of them, I've already done the Mondays going 10+  years back in the archives ...

Steven,
This is not the same Gary Larson.

@Barry Ancona

Where's David Steinberg when you need him?

@Steven M.,

He‚Äôs actually the author and illustrator of a very popular series of graphic novels called *Hazardous Tales* written for young readers, largely biographies of important people in American history. My grandson is a huge fan.

@NYC Traveler

@SBK,

That would be Nathan Hale.

@NYC Traveler

I feel both happy and embarrassed to say that I understand your comment.

@Steven M., He actually did. I think that‚Äôs what started him down that road. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathan_Hale_(author) This doesn‚Äôt mention that he also constructs puzzles for the NYT, but I can‚Äôt find that webpage where I saw it.
I once had that problem with an answer clued as an old song that had to be MEAN TOME. A song about an unkind book?

@Francis

What's more, it's a kealoa, since the answer to that clue could just as easily have been "seethe."

@Michael B.

I was similarly confused by  2D - what does a ski jump have to do with a CAT CHAIR? Shouldn't the clue be, "Your lap, perhaps?"

@Steve L

I made my comment in jest without even reading the column!
@Francis I eventually figured that out, though thank you for introducing me to the term "dook".  We can make that into a verb, right?  "Man, I dooked 43D."

@Molly in Wake Forest
Would MIZZLED be an acceptable clue for that word?

@Michael B.
Seems like only yesterday I was trying to figure out MISDO. üôÑ üòÅ

@Molly in Wake Forest
I think MIZZLE really exists as a weather word -- MIST + DRIZZLE.
@SBK Found 'mizzle' defined here: https://weather.com/news/weather/news/2023-02-14-weather-words-mizzle and they provide a usage example from 200+ years ago.

@Cat Lady Margaret

Candy corn tastes very nostalgic to me.

@Francis
Is that 'nostalgic' or 'past its SELL BY date'? So hard to tell...

@Steve L

I am the right demographic and I hated that stuff! That and circus peanuts, which my younger sisters inexplicably clamored for. [Shudder]

@Cat Lady Margaret
As youngsters, my kids enjoyed candy corn. As adults, they call it ‚Äúa headache in a bag.‚Äù

@Teresa

Same here. Getting candy corn in my trick or treat basket was always a big disappointment. I also hated circus peanuts. And don‚Äôt even get me started on Peeps‚Ä¶

@Megan
And Hannukah is receding into the distance, leaving me to pick off the dribs and drabs of wax that accumulated on the menorah. Sigh.
Chris, https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/enbanc

@Chris
Read this answer as EN BANC, from French for "on the benc."  Refers to a court case adjudicated by all the judges of the court, rather than a smaller panel of the judges.

@Kenny
Oops, typo, should have been "on the bench,"
@Chris As I filled in what was a gimme for me (a lawyer), I wondered how many people would be mystified by it.

@john ezra

Upscale puzzle, I'd say.
@john ezra What are the Griddies? Or was that comment ALL IN FUN? When I looked it up, I found NADA.

Hi Elena -- thanks for asking...each year some volunteers arrange to give an award to the best xword puzzles, which we've named The Griddies. There are four categories: M-W puzzles, Thursday, Fri-Sat, and Sundays. I've been doing the drum-beating this year and people (anyone) can leave under my announcements their nominations for the Puzzle of the Year in each of those categories. They can nominate as many as they like. Two other people from this list are also helping - Eric Hougland and Marshall Walthew -- if you scroll through the comments today or any other day you'll likely see their names, too. Eric does most of the work -- we construct a ballot which will be available to vote on early in January. So, if there are any puzzles you want to nominate, please do so under one of my messages and I'll gather them up. Thanks for asking!

@Maxwell Edison

Let's get something straight.  You just don't like "playground retort" clues.  And that's fine.  Others have no problem with them; they're just one of many different quirks that appear in crosswords that experienced solvers learn to just enter and move to the next clue without a lingering thought.

That does not have anything to do with the constructor's ambition or lack thereof.  When you characterize this as "lazy," all you're doing is reducing your credibility to zero.  As you said, it's there for a good reason.  I'm sure you couldn't rework that section to get rid of it; I certainly don't see a way to do it.

So fine, don't like something; that's just fine.  But don't call it "lazy" just because you don't like it.

@Maxwell Edison

So, Maxwell, not sure if you construct, but it‚Äôs not lazy‚Äîsometimes certain phrases come up and you have to use them to avoid worse fill elsewhere. Of course it‚Äôs trite and a little clunky‚Äîand if I am constructing I will try to avoid it. But if I can‚Äôt without messing it up worse‚Äîand this is particularly true for early week fill‚Äî then you go with it. But I guarantee you this constructor spent a lot of time coming up with the best fill they could.

@Steve L
IS THAT SO?
SAYS WHO?

I'm not a fan of the "playground retorts" clues either, because the answer is never "So's your old man."

@Grant

In Brooklyn, it was "your mother wears army boots."

@Steve L
In London it was once, ‚ÄúYour mother wears short skirts‚Äù which 11-year olds were able to interpret easily and launch a full on attack.

@dutchiris
Anyone else start confidently putting in POTATOLATKES at 20A, only to hesitate and peter out about six or seven spaces in?

@dutchiris

I‚Äôll join you in skipping the CANDY CORN. Even as a kid, I didn‚Äôt understand its appeal.

@Matt
You're forgetting there are four theme answers, CUPCAKE. Forgive me the overfamiliararity.

@Vaeris 

is overfamiliararity a neologism for a rare overfamiliarity?

@Matt
Nah, just bad proof reading with allergy-blurred eyes.

@C

I'm actually wondering if a reply I did, positing that the American economy was an cooperative oligarchy, may have incensed enough people here to bring down the whole thread.

So in that case, it is I who should be boycotting, right Andrzej?   Would you come back if I left?

@Vaer

Thanks. I haven‚Äôt been hanging around here much in the last week and missed Andrzej‚Äôs departure announcement.

@Emu fodder
Madeira sounds like a great idea -- both the island and the drink. Enjoy!

@C

I suspect he's still among us. Undercover.

@Emu fodder

There he is!

Today feels better.

Enjoy Madeira.

@Vaer
I read all the comments every night and didn't see that. I've been missing him, too. But I do think he's back under the name Emu fodder. Read the later comments, which I also posted about on ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ's post.

@Times Rita
I'm aware of his pseudonym.  I was only saying what he said he was going to do.  I can't help if  he can't not post.

@C
No disrespect, but I kinda enjoy the break.

@C I put my subscription on hold for about a week and look what I missed! I was expecting to hear about a December holiday, not emu interventions. I‚Äôm glad it‚Äôs not a full blackout. I very much enjoy auditing his classes

After touring the Baltics and getting a sense of life where the walls have ears, censorship by emu takes on a new gravity

@Enid

Was anybody forcing you to read my posts? If not, you do realize hate reads are a kind of expression of love and admiration?

@Emu fodder
Not Enid. Never forced to read your posts. But no, 'hate reads' do not express love any more than 'hate posts' do. Still glad to have evidence of your continued existence under whatever guise.

@SBK

Oh c'mon, have you never been at least somewhat - and quite disturbingly - fascinated by a person you hated with every fiber of your being? I know I have!

@Heidi
I remember a quote from the play 1776 (Andrzej alert: it's a m--ical!), from the Ben Franklin character (roughly):

Those who would sacrifice their liberty for safety deserve neither liberty nor safety.

But, in the spirit of Nils Bohr, I add (from the Mishnah):

Pray for the welfare of the government for, were it not for that, people would swallow each other alive.

@Emu fodder

Last comment: I do wish that ONLY so-called offensive comments got removed, rather than an entire thread. That would not only preserve the polite discourse, it would send a signal to the relevant poster that they somehow crossed a line.

But in terms of general moderation: this is, after all, a forum to discuss the day‚Äôs crossword. There are plenty of other forums for discussion of politics and other non-crossword-related topics. Many people come here to get away from all that, and their wishes should also be respected. I think we‚Äôre given a pretty loose leash in general, but I can‚Äôt fault the mods for wanting to rein us in from time to time, when things go too far afield or get contentious. I‚Äôve been on boards where there is no moderation, and it‚Äôs not pretty.

Personally, if I could add one rule (other than to delete individual comments rather than a whole thread), it would be to delete any comments that refer to the crossword constructor as ‚Äúlazy‚Äù. SO annoying.

@Heidi

I understand your position, but coming from a formerly autocratic country, and having also experienced attempts to silence me by private individuals throughout my life, I personally will never look favorably at any arbitrary control of speech. The least the NYT could do is provide us with a list of terms that cause posts to be withheld, and clear criteria for deleting posts. They can't be bothered to do either of those things ü§∑üèΩ

(The one time in my life I received d3a th thr3 ats was for speaking my mind. And no, it was not online. In high school I was visited by a girl and her two muscular male friends who told me I'd better 5h ‚úìt ‚úìp about my beliefs, or else. Maybe these days they work as mods?)

@Emu fodder

No.

@SBK

I find that surprising, and a little weird üòÆ
@Mike At first I read ‚Äúcrumby‚Äù as ‚Äúcrumbly‚Äù but now I get that the joke only works with Noel

@Mike

@Mike
Dough!  Glad to see you were able to press some out today.

@SP

Two a-penny
Hot Cross Puns!
(Usually for Easter, but what the heck)

@Mike

@Sam Lyons

You‚Äôre welcome to any CANDY CORN that I somehow acquire. It‚Äôs right next to Peeps on my list of undesirable candies.

@Eric Hougland

Peeps? Eeks, nooo. But might you have some smarties lying around there, kind sir? Because that would make my sugar bliss complete.
@Eric Hougland I LOVE candy corn!

Thank you. I thought I was alone in my aversion. My sisters used to actually ask for them whenever our dad came back from a business trip. Why then I don't know. Maybe our local stores refused to stock them and he had to score them in another city on the black market.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Sunday from February 25, 2018 by Will Nediger. Don't recall another one like this. Six pairs of theme answers - the pairs crossing each other as across and down, and.. the down answer would be straightforwardly clued while the crossing down answer would add the phrase... "Spelled using only the letters of... 2 down" (e.g.) - every one referencing the crossing down answer. Some of those pairs. 2 down: "Historical period" IRONAGE 22 across: "Historical period spelled using only the letters of 2-Down" GEORGIANERA and 13 down - "Revolutionary War hero" ETHANALLEN 28 across - "Revolutionary War hero spelled using only the letters of 13-Down" NATHANHALE and 39 down - "Really impressive" OUTSTANDING 95 across - "Really impressive, spelled using only the letters of 39-Down" ASTOUNDING And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/25/2018&g=28&d=A ...

Thanks for the description of life in Whitehorse, in a previous reply.

I love reading about the north.  It surprised me that you only get a couple of feet of snow.  I tend to think that it just gets snowier and snowier as one gets farther north.

@Karen

Here's how dumb I am about some things.  After many years of ignoring college sports, I turned to the radio and heard about how well the Yukon team was doing.  I thought, "that's strange--all the way up in the Yukon?  Well, maybe there's not much to do in the winter so they got really good at basketball."

I loved the idea until I realized they were talking about the University of Connecticut, UConn.

I'm not much of a traveler, but if urgent business ever call me to Whitehorse, I'll be in touch.
